The video features a presentation slide discussing the "Split Brain Issue" in the context of Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) NameNode High Availability (HA) architecture. The slide is divided into two sections: on the left, there is a textual explanation of the issue, and on the right, a diagram illustrating the HDFS NameNode HA architecture. The text explains that in a typical HA cluster, two separate machines are configured as NameNodes, with one in an Active state and the other in a Standby state. The Active NameNode handles all client operations, while the Standby NameNode maintains enough state to provide a fast failover if necessary. The diagram shows the components of the HDFS NameNode HA architecture, including the Active and Standby NameNodes, Quorum Journal Nodes, and DataNodes, along with their interactions and data flow. The slide also highlights the importance of the Standby node having up-to-date information regarding the location of blocks in the cluster to ensure a fast failover. The background of the slide is a gradient of blue shades, and there is a small image of a person in the bottom right corner, likely the presenter. The text is presented in bullet points, with key terms highlighted in bold for emphasis. The overall atmosphere of the video is educational, aimed at explaining technical concepts related to HDFS and HA architecture.

The video features a presentation slide discussing the "Split Brain Issue: Solution" in the context of Hadoop's NameNode management. The slide explains that JournalNodes ensure only one NameNode acts as a writer at a time, and introduces "Fencing" as a solution for split brain scenarios. It details how to implement Fencing by adding a mechanism in the `hdfs-site.xml` file, with an example XML property snippet shown in a blue box. The text explains that the "Fencing Method Name" refers to scripts or Java classes used to fence the Active NameNode during a failover.
